speaker: Pippa
text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Pippa.

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m Neil.

speaker: Pippa
text: Now, Neil, have you ever wanted to be a musician?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes, Pippa, I still want to be a musician. I've been playing my guitar since I was 14.

speaker: Pippa
text: Wow. Well, maybe one day you'll, you'll manage it. Who knows?

speaker: Neil
text: What about you?

speaker: Pippa
text: I don't think I'd like to be a musician. I think it would be a bit stressful. Especially if you had lots of fans and were really successful.

speaker: Neil
text: Yeah. I wonder what life as a musician is actually like? We’ll be finding that out in this programme as we hear from some people around the UK who would like to become successful musicians, and we’ll even listen to some of their music too.

speaker: Pippa
text: But first, I have a question for you, Neil.

speaker: Pippa
text: In the UK, we have a weekly chart of the best-selling songs in the country. And the top selling song is called the number one. But which musical artist do you think has had the most UK number one songs?

speaker: Pippa
text: a) The Beatles

speaker: Pippa
text: b) Ed Sheeran

speaker: Pippa
text: c) Elvis Presley

speaker: Neil
text: Oh well, I think that's easy. It must be, surely, The Beatles.

speaker: Pippa
text: Well, I’ll reveal the answer at the end of the programme.

speaker: Pippa
text: Now, getting a number one song is a dream for many musicians. But if you want to become a musician, where do you start?

speaker: open mics
text: I grew up in a really rich music scene in St Ives. I was going to open mics from the age of about 11.

speaker: open mic nightsOpen mic nights
text: This is Bailey. She lives in St Ives in Cornwall on the south-west coast of England. She says she was going to open mic nights from a young age. Open mic nights are events where anyone can sing or play music.

speaker: Pippa
text: Bailey talked about her life as a musician to BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.

speaker: songwriters' circles bunchtook me under their wing
text: I would go to these songwriters' circles at the Kettle and Wink on, like, a Friday night after school where I'd be, like, the youngest person by, like, 50 years. But I'd sit in a circle with a bunch of old men, and they'd play James Taylor and Carole King and The Eagles and lots of 70s music, and I guess that's influenced me massively. But I guess, you know, everyone kind of took me under their wing growing up.

speaker: songwriters' circles
text: When she was younger, Bailey went to songwriters' circles. These are meetings for people interested in writing their own music.

speaker: bunchbunch
text: Bailey remembers sitting with a bunch of old men. A bunch is an informal way to talk about a group of people.

speaker: took her under their wingtake somebody under your wing
text: The older men in the group would play music from the 1970s, and Bailey says they took her under their wing. If you take somebody under your wing you decide to protect them or guide them.

speaker: Pippa
text: Let’s meet another musician, Josh.

speaker: busking
text: So, I learnt my first proper song on guitar when I was about 13. I literally started busking the moment I could kind of do that.

speaker: busker
text: Josh lives in London and is a busker. This means that he performs on the street or in public places to earn money.

speaker: Busking
text: Busking is a common way for musicians to make money and perform to more people. And as Josh told BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home, it can help musicians to get new opportunities.

speaker: main earnergigsowe a lot tobusking
text: It's been kind of like my main earner that's kept me going for the last ten or so years. From that, it's then got me various different opportunities. It's got me all my gigs, it's got me all my connections. So I owe a lot to busking.

speaker: main earner
text: Busking is Josh’s main earner, it’s his main source of money.

speaker: buskinggigsGigs
text: He says that busking has got him all his gigs and connections. Gigs are musical concerts. It’s an informal, slang word.

speaker: owes a lot toowe a lot
text: Josh says he owes a lot to busking. If you owe a lot to someone or something, you have success or happiness because of that person or thing.

speaker: owes a lot toowe a lot
text: So, would you like to listen to some of Josh’s music, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Of course I would.

speaker: Pippa
text: Well, here’s a bit of his song That Side of the Wall, which he performed for BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.

speaker: Clip from song
text: Can you leave me something

speaker: Clip from song
text: Can you leave it by the door

speaker: Clip from song
text: So I know there's something

speaker: Clip from song
text: Or someone

speaker: Clip from song
text: That side of the wall

speaker: Clip from song
text: Stop the heat from coming

speaker: Clip from song
text: 'Cause I always liked the cold

speaker: Clip from song
text: I need some belonging

speaker: Clip from song
text: Or someone

speaker: Clip from song
text: That side of the wall

speaker: Neil
text: Wow. Josh is pretty good, isn't he?. I’d love to hear more.

speaker: Pippa
text: Well you can find performances by the musicians in the series on our website – bbclearningenglish.com. We’ll also put a link in the notes below this episode!

speaker: Neil
text: OK. So, what about your question, Pippa?

speaker: Pippa
text: Yes, I asked which artist had the most number one songs in the UK charts? The Beatles, Ed Sheeran or Elvis Presley?

speaker: Pippa
text: And you said The Beatles, Neil. But the answer is actually Elvis Presley. He's had 21 number one songs and The Beatles have had 18.

speaker: Neil
text: Really? Well that's OK, I love 'the King' as well.

speaker: Pippa
text: OK.

speaker: open mic nights
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned in this musical episode, starting with open mic nights, events where anyone can sing or play music.

speaker: Songwriters' circles
text: Songwriters' circles are meetings for people interested in writing their own music.

speaker: bunch
text: A bunch of people is a group of people.

speaker: take someone under your wing
text: The expression take someone under your wing means to protect or guide someone.

speaker: Buskingbusker
text: Busking is performing in a public place for money, and a busker is someone who performs on the street for money.

speaker: main earner
text: Your main earner is your main source of income.

speaker: Gigs
text: Gigs are musical concerts.

speaker: toowe a lot to
text: And the expression to owe a lot to someone or something, means to have success or happiness because of that person or thing.

speaker: Neil
text: Once again our six minutes are up, but you can find My Song, My Home on our website – bbclearningenglish.com. Watch the songs and sing along, and learn more about the vocabulary in the lyrics!

speaker: Pippa
text: We’ll see you again soon for some more trending topics and useful vocabulary. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
